title: Bacterial Meningitis Score for Children
description: Predicts likelihood of bacterial (versus aseptic) meningitis in children with CSF pleocytosis. The score helps clinicians distinguish between bacterial and aseptic meningitis to support safe discharge decisions while maintaining appropriate caution for this serious condition.

parameters.name: seizure_at_presentation
parameters.description: Seizure at or prior to initial presentation

result.name: bacterial_meningitis_score
result.description: Total score indicating risk of bacterial meningitis (0-5 points)

ranges.description: Very low risk of bacterial meningitis
ranges.interpretation: Score of 0 indicates very low risk of bacterial meningitis (risk approximately 0.1%). Consider discharge with close follow-up. Clinical judgment should always supersede the score. Consider single dose of parenteral antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone) prior to discharge while awaiting bacterial cultures.

ranges.description: Not very low risk of bacterial meningitis
ranges.interpretation: Score ≥1 indicates patient is not very low risk for bacterial meningitis. Admission for parenteral antibiotics and monitoring is recommended while awaiting CSF culture results. Higher scores correlate with increased likelihood of bacterial meningitis.

references: Nigrovic LE, Kuppermann N, Macias CG, et al. Clinical prediction rule for identifying children with cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis at very low risk of bacterial meningitis. JAMA. 2007 Jan 3;297(1):52-60. doi: 10.1001/jama.297.1.52.

Nigrovic LE, Malley R, Macias CG, et al. Effect of antibiotic pretreatment on cerebrospinal fluid profiles of children with bacterial meningitis. Pediatrics. 2008 Oct;122(4):726-30. doi: 10.1542/peds.2007-3275.
Nigrovic LE, Malley R, Kuppermann N. Meta-analysis of bacterial meningitis score validation studies. Arch Dis Child. 2012 Sep;97(9):799-805. doi: 10.1136/archdischild-2012-301798.
formula: Score = (Positive Gram stain × 1) + (CSF ANC ≥1,000 × 1) + (CSF protein ≥80 × 1) + (Peripheral blood ANC ≥10,000 × 1) + (Seizure at presentation × 1)
notes: Not recommended for use in patients <2 months old
Not effective for ruling out all nervous system infections (e.g., Lyme meningitis)
Clinical judgment should always supersede the score
Particular caution should be exercised in infants with petechial rashes
Consider regional epidemiology (e.g., Lyme disease prevalence) when interpreting results
